social_posts.post_text: Barcelona Tile Cookie Bar v2. If you’ve been to Barcelona you may have noticed these beautiful tiles paving the sidewalks. Designed by architect Antoni Gaudi in 1904 they are an emblem of that city (specifically in the Passeig de Gracia area). I first started making this cookie in 2018 and have made an updated version which you can see in the step by step images as you swipe left. The components are: salted caramel - cacao nib praline - sablée cookies and dark chocolate. The top cookie is branded using a metal stamp that was made by a 3D printer.
Putting this image upfront from yesterday’s post on Barcelona Tile Cookie Bars because I like it so much. (Sablée cookies with salted caramel, cocoa nib praline and dark chocolate coating)

Agave Bar. Smoked marshmallow, blood orange marmalade and mezcal ganache in a dark chocolate shell. The mold is my design and custom made. I was going to spray it with green cocoa butter but when I was testing the mold with plain chocolate I really liked the clean, shiny chocolate look. I have nothing against using cocoa butter colors but do I need to use it ALL THE TIME? The answer is no. It shouldn’t automatically be the first impulse, at least not for me. It got me thinking too, that colored chocolate shells have become ubiquitous. Is it that plain chocolate bores us? I don’t have the answers but an interesting challenge would be to think of a whole line of chocolates (cast in polycarbonate molds, not enrobed… you see a lot less colored cocoa butter in enrobed chocolates and more creative use of texture and patterns) with no colors. What would that look like?
Chocolate bar? Entremet? Can it be both? Yes. Passion fruit pate de fruit, coconut dacquoise and coconut gianduja in a white chocolate shell. Merry Christmas Eve!

Some of my favorites from 2022. I want to wish you all a very happy new year!  From left to right: 
1. Choux doughnut filled with diplomat cream
2. Peanut praline sorbet filled dried red chili
3. Whiskey bar: oak flavored marshmallow, whiskey and caramel ganache, crispy feulletine base 
4. Black Forest cake 2022
5. Panettone ❤️
6. Blueberry “chocolate” and candied Yuzu peel
7. Vanilla sablé cookies with passion fruit vanillla pate de fruit and caramel ganache 
8. Mont Blanc 2022
9. Galette de Rois 2022

On the cover of @sogoodmag, a huge honor to be sure. This is an interpretation of a Root Beer Float. Using hoja santa (holy leaf), known in some parts as “root beer leaf” for its flavor, and a whipped vanilla Chantilly cream filling. The whole thing is freeze dried so it is crispy/ crunchy. The flavors combine in the mouth to makes us think of a root beer float but with completely different ingredients. This is an idea to simplify (not dumb down) desserts to make them more sustainable by using less resources to create delicious food. Recipe in the new #sogood issue 29.

French Toast Chocolate Bar. Rum and cinnamon ganache soaked toasted brioche and salted maple sugar caramel. Using bread as an inclusion is unusual but I highly recommend it - I soak the toasted brioche through completely by pouring the loose ganache over the toasted slices of brioche and then pulling a vacuum to soak it through. I first came up with this idea over a decade ago and used it as a flavor in one of the individual bonbons in the sampler box we sold at Hudson Chocolates. But this mold shape made me want to revisit it and tie in the shape with a corresponding flavor.

Flying solo this Valentine’s Day? S’mores Cookie Sandwich. Graham cracker cookies, milk chocolate ganache and marshmallow. This is a throwback to valentines 2013 and 2021.  So, if you’ve seen it before, now you can see it again. Original shape and form by @anthonylentjewelry

Red Velvet Cake Chocolate Bar - red velvet cake crumbs are baked and dehydrated then ground to fine crumbs and mixed with clarified butter to form the thin layers. The ganache is cream cheese based so it’s slightly tart and sour, just like cream cheese. White chocolate shell.
Sakura. Cherry blossom and vanilla Chantilly, cherry compote, cherry blossom cake. Cherry and vanilla blossom infusion as an aromatic component.
Conchas Negras. Black Conchas. Filled with cajeta (goat’s milk caramel). They’re black because they are made with black cocoa powder. Not ash or food coloring.
Tête de Moine - pear butter - crispy feuille de brick tart - balsamic reduction. Tête de Moine is one of my favorite cheeses. More cheese for dessert.

Gâteau Marjolaine Bar. This is inspired by Fernand Point’s Gâteau Marjolaine which consists of layers of hazelnut dacquoise, praline buttercream and chocolate ganache. I wanted to translate this into a bar, and did so with this mold I made. I added candied hazelnuts as well. I like the idea of using cake in chocolate bars. Not everything needs to last for months on a shelf. Swipe left to see a cross section cut.

Rhubarb cheesecake and graham cracker crust. Strips of thinly sliced rhubarb, compressed and cooked sous vide with an elderflower syrup, no-bake cheesecake filling and a crisp graham cracker crust. These are two versions of the same idea.

Matisse Bars. I’ve always liked the graphic elements of Henri Matisse’s work and I used them as inspiration for these bars (4 inches/ 10 cm long - 0.5inches/1.25cm deep). I made the molds by laser cutting plexiglass with these 4 shapes and then using the resulting forms to make the mold in a thermoforming machine. If you swipe to the left, the bars are, clockwise from top left: - Blueberry “chocolate”, dried Thai banana pieces 
- Raspberry “chocolate”, salted toasted sesame seeds 
- Pistachio “chocolate”, freeze dried raspberries 
- Mango “chocolate”, lime zest
Pleated Chocolate Bar. 64% chocolate shell, mascarpone ganache, brown butter financier, crispy gianduja. Incorporating shelf stable cakes to chocolate bars is a favorite.
Caramelized Sugar Rice Pudding Eclair - eclair filled with rice pudding, coated with sugar and then caramelized. One of the best things I’ve eaten.
U Bar. Sour cream ganache, marshmallow, and salted caramel strips as inclusions, white chocolate shell, chocolate shortbread hat. Swipe left for cross cut.

Koji Fermented Okinawa Sweet Potato and Koji Fermented Forbidden Rice Sherbet. This is my dessert for the newest edition of @revistadulcypas #500th edition issue. Find the recipe there. Swipe all the way left to see the effect of these beautiful spores on the rice and the sweet potato
Mocha Eclair. Eclair and glaze are made with black cocoa powder, coffee infused pastry cream filling.
Chicharrón - dark chocolate - chipotle powder - salt - tasty dried flower petals.

Picasso Museum 60th Anniversary Bar. A few months ago I was asked to create a bar to celebrate the 60th anniversary of the Picasso Museum in Barcelona. Having visited the museum on many occasions I chose a painting titled “Menina 8” as inspiration for the bar. I also chose to make as many elements for the bar as possible by hand. I made the chocolate from scratch using cacao beans from Ghana (to produce a 60% chocolate for a 60th anniversary commemoration). I sculpted the mold with epoxy clay which I used to make the polycarbonate molds using a thermoforming machine. The graphic elements of the wrapper I made using a rubber mat that I carved and then inked and pressed onto the paper, a method known as linocut. I did not make the stickers that close the wrapper, but I did design them. If you swipe all the way left you will see short videos which show the processes mentioned as well as @pere_castells who orchestrated all this with Tonina Cerdà from the Picasso museum, and then some lucky winners who scored this bar (Víctor Minguela, Sabela Patiño and Manuel Galarza). It was a wonderful creative opportunity for me, and I am honored to have been a part of this celebration. Gracias Pere!
Some of my favorite Bûche de Noël throughout the years. Wishing all of you a wonderful Christmas Day, and, if you don’t celebrate, I hope you have a wonderful day as well. Cheers.
Pastry Chef - Author; Seattle, WA.
